Description: Body fragment of an Attic black-figured pottery olpe. Horse or centaur to the right; remaining are his tail, hindquarters, and part of his belly; added red on the genitals, belly, and thigh.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Greco-Roman Museum, Alexandria. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Venit: 'Manner of the Gorgon Painter. Unusual since the Gorgon painter and other members of his workshop rarely decorate olpai with horses, but compare Agora P 18531 (ABV 11, 14; Paralipomena 7, 14 [with correct number]; Agora 23: pl. 64 no. 673). The parts of the horse that are preserved on the Naukratis fragment are lacking on the fragmentary olpe from the Agora, but details of drawing are paralleled on Baltimore, Walters Art Gallery 48.215 (ABV 9, 18; Paralipomena 7, 18; JdL 76 [1961] 28 fig. 29).'
This may be a centaur; the incised knee-caps point in that direction.
Bibliographic references: Venit 1988 / Greek Painted Pottery from Naukratis in Egyptian Museums (p. 80 no. 267 pl. 60)
Venit 1984 / Early Attic Black Figure Vases in Egypt (p. 145 fig. 7)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GA.1208)
